content:
Burnley Borough Council has approximately £13 million in uncollected council tax debt — a sum roughly equivalent to its entire annual net revenue budget. While deprivation is a significant factor in non-payment, it does not fully explain a debt mountain of this scale. Collection processes, enforcement activity, and the performance of the outsourced revenues service all play a role — and all deserve scrutiny.

The Scale of the Problem

Approximately £13 million in council tax remains uncollected across multiple financial years. To put this in perspective:

  • Burnley's net revenue budget is approximately £15 million per year
  • The uncollected debt therefore represents roughly 87% of one year's entire budget
  • Even if only 50% of this debt were recoverable, it would represent £6.5 million — more than enough to close the council's projected funding gap

Collection Rates Over Time

Year Council Tax Set Amount Collected (est.) In-Year Collection Rate Arrears Added (est.)
2020/21 ~£45M ~£42.3M ~94.0% ~£2.7M
2021/22 ~£46M ~£43.7M ~95.0% ~£2.3M
2022/23 ~£48M ~£45.6M ~95.0% ~£2.4M
2023/24 ~£50M ~£47.5M ~95.0% ~£2.5M
2024/25 ~£52M ~£49.4M ~95.0% ~£2.6M

Note: These are estimated figures based on available data. The total council tax figure includes the Burnley Borough element, Lancashire County Council precept, Police and Crime Commissioner precept, and Fire Authority precept. Burnley collects on behalf of all precepting authorities.

How Burnley Compares

Council In-Year Collection Rate Comparison
National Average (England) ~96.0% Benchmark
Burnley ~95.0% Below national average
Hyndburn ~94.5% Below Burnley
Pendle ~95.5% Above Burnley

One percentage point of council tax collection in Burnley represents approximately £500,000 per year. Even a modest improvement in collection rates could generate significant additional income without raising council tax.

The Deprivation Factor

Burnley is one of the most deprived boroughs in England, ranking in the bottom 10% nationally on the Index of Multiple Deprivation. This context is important:

  • Many residents genuinely cannot afford to pay — they are choosing between council tax and heating or food
  • A high proportion of residents receive Council Tax Support (the replacement for Council Tax Benefit), which reduces the collectible amount
  • High levels of household transience — people moving frequently — make collection more difficult
  • A large proportion of Band A properties means lower average bills but also lower income per household for the council

Deprivation is a genuine mitigating factor. But it does not explain the full £13 million. Other deprived boroughs achieve better collection rates, and the growing debt mountain suggests that collection processes themselves may not be effective enough.

The Liberata Factor

Until 2026, revenues and benefits services — including council tax collection — have been outsourced to Liberata UK Ltd under a contract worth over £21 million across its lifetime.

Key questions about Liberata's collection performance:

  • What are the contractual collection rate targets? Is Liberata meeting them?
  • What incentives exist for Liberata to pursue older, harder-to-collect debt?
  • Is Liberata's performance better or worse than an in-house collection team would achieve?
  • As the contract ends in 2026, will the transition back to in-house services affect collection activity?

The Cost of Collection

There is a point at which chasing old debt costs more than it recovers. The council must balance:

  • Cost of enforcement: Court costs, bailiff fees, officer time, legal expenses
  • Recovery rate: What percentage of enforced debt is actually collected?
  • Social impact: Aggressive enforcement in deprived areas can cause genuine hardship
  • Write-off policy: At what point is debt deemed uncollectable and written off?

A rational approach would segment the £13 million debt by age and collectability, focusing enforcement resources where recovery is most likely and writing off genuinely uncollectable debt to avoid wasting further money pursuing it.

Questions That Need Answering

  1. What is the age profile of the £13M debt? How much is less than 1 year old, 1-3 years, 3-5 years, and over 5 years?
  2. How much is deemed uncollectable? What proportion of the debt has been assessed as having no realistic prospect of recovery?
  3. What is the annual cost of collection activity? How much does it cost to pursue outstanding debt, and what is the return on that investment?
  4. What write-off policy is in place? When and how are debts formally written off?
  5. What are Liberata's contractual KPIs for collection? Are they meeting targets?
  6. What happens to outstanding debt when services return in-house? Will the transition disrupt collection activity?
  7. What is the council's approach to vulnerable debtors? Are hardship policies in place for residents who genuinely cannot pay?

This article is based on publicly available information including council financial statements, DLUHC council tax collection statistics, and published performance data. Some figures are estimates based on available data and are clearly marked as such. Council tax collection is a complex area with many variables — deprivation, household transience, and support eligibility all affect outcomes. This analysis does not constitute financial or legal advice.
